conclusion: To determine when the two objects are farthest apart, analyze the distance each object has traveled over time.
Distance between them is maximized when the difference in their positions is greatest.
Position of an object can be found by integrating its velocity.
Distance between two objects at times is the absolute value of the difference in their positions.
At t = t1, both A and B have non-zero velocity but the velocities differ.
Since v_A(t1) < v_B(t1), A is behind B.
At t = t2, object A reaches its maximum velocity and then starts decelerating.
Object B continues to accelerate until it reaches v0 at t3.
After t2, object A decelerates and eventually stops at t4.
Object B continues to accelerate beyond v0 and maintains this speed.
Maximum distance occurs when they are moving in opposite directions or when the rate of change of the distance is zero.
From the graph, tangents at points where velocities are equal indicate these instants.
Maximum distance occurs just before t2, where velocities are equal and rate of change of separation is minimized.
The two objects are farthest apart at time t2.
